{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3494864,"name":"Zach","username":"rutmanz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rutmanz/{size}/168738_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T17:36:41.497Z","cooked":"

Our school has access points that support 5ghz, 6ghz, and 2.4ghz, and we’re interested in using these as an access point for the vividhosting radios to facilitate 5ghz communication.

We’ve been able to connect the robot radios to this network (as indicated by their /status page), but other devices connected have been unable to reach the robot radio, presumably due to a configuration issue on the AP.

To be clear, intended use case is for laptops to connect to the school’s non-vividhosting AP and be able to communicate with the robot’s network (without adjusting network adapter settings like static ip on the laptops)

What settings/configuration options are required on the AP to make this work?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-01-28T17:36:41.497Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":31,"reads":130,"readers_count":129,"score":186.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":483992,"topic_slug":"generic-access-point-with-robot-radio","display_username":"Zach","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52320,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1540 Software"},"post_url":"/t/generic-access-point-with-robot-radio/483992/1","custom_user_title":"1540 Software","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3494912,"name":"alst","username":"alst","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/alst/{size}/11646_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T18:23:55.008Z","cooked":"
rutmanz:

We’ve been able to connect the robot radios to this network (as indicated by their /status page), but other devices connected have been unable to reach the robot radio

How are you accessing the /status page? Over ethernet?

rutmanz:

What settings/configuration options are required on the AP to make this work?

If you mean on the school’s AP:

  • Some public/large networks (like in schools) block local traffic between clients. It’s possible you might be running into this. If that’s the case, I highly doubt your school would be open to changing that setting, but maybe there’s some sort of allow-list your devices could be added to.
  • In general, you’ll want your devices (including the radio) to all be on the 10.TE.AM.* subnet. This may not be possible if your school is already using that range for something else, or is using a different class of subnet entirely (172.16-31.* or 192.168.*).

alst:

How are you accessing the /status page? Over ethernet?

Yes, over ethernet

Would the 10.TE.AM.0/24 subnet be that be all that’s required? Does the school’s AP need to be at a particular IP address or just somewhere in the subnet?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-01-28T23:26:35.489Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":75,"readers_count":74,"score":20.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":483992,"topic_slug":"generic-access-point-with-robot-radio","display_username":"Zach","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52320,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1540 Software"},"post_url":"/t/generic-access-point-with-robot-radio/483992/3","custom_user_title":"1540 Software","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3495235,"name":"alst","username":"alst","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/alst/{size}/11646_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-29T00:15:45.725Z","cooked":"

10.TE.AM.24 or broader should be ok. Barring any firewall rules/etc., any two devices in that range and with a subnet that includes that range should be able to talk to each other.

It would be a good idea to make sure nothing else on the network is using the 10.TE.AM.{1-10} range. Other than that, I don’t think the school’s AP IP should matter.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-01-29T00:18:52.328Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":59,"readers_count":58,"score":11.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":483992,"topic_slug":"generic-access-point-with-robot-radio","display_username":"alst","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":52320,"username":"rutmanz","name":"Zach","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rutmanz/{size}/168738_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25570,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FiM CSA/etc."},"post_url":"/t/generic-access-point-with-robot-radio/483992/4","custom_user_title":"FiM CSA/etc.","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3495343,"name":"Fletcher","username":"FletcherS7","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletchers7/{size}/168995_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-29T02:58:16.273Z","cooked":"

It would be more practical to setup a dedicated SSID and VLAN for this configuration.

rough outline on what you’ll need to do here.

[FRC Blog] New Radios at 2024 FIRST Championship General Forum
Create an SSID on your shop Access Point with just your team number. Then configure your radio in Team Client/STA Mode and set the 6GHz WPA/SAE key to the same as your shop 6GHz SSID WPA/SAE key. Your robot radio will now connect to the Access Point as a 6GHz client. You’ll want to make sure the network of the SSID you create does not have any devices that conflict with the robot (10.TE.AM.1 is the radio, 10.TE.AM.2 is the rio, etc). and does not have a DHCP range that conflicts with the rob…

Just also setup a 5GHz network (with whatever SSID) on the same VLAN.
